msItem.title: Letter to Major J.O. Nelson

msItem.note: Autograph letter to Major J.O. Nelson, governor of Reading Gaol, expressing gratitude for his kindness in prison and reflecting on suffering, prison life, and the possibility of reforming the system.

support.p: Autograph letter written in ink on paper, comprising four leaves, headed “Hotel de la Plage, Berneval-sur-Mer, Près de Dieppe”.

origin.p: Written at Berneval-sur-Mer on 28 May 1897, after Wilde’s release from Reading Gaol, and addressed to Major J.O. Nelson, governor of the prison.

bibl.title: The Case of Warder Martin: Some Cruelties of Prison Life
bibl.author: Oscar Wilde
bibl.note: The Case of Warder Martin: Some Cruelties of Prison Life is a pamphlet first published anonymously in London in 1896 and later reissued under the expanded title Children in Prison and Other Cruelties of Prison Life. Although the 1896 printing was anonymous, the themes and arguments closely anticipate those expressed by Oscar Wilde in his public letter to the editor of The Daily Chronicle (France, 27 May 1897), where he discussed “the Martin case” as evidence of a system in need of urgent reform. This pamphlet denounces the mistreatment of child prisoners at Reading Gaol, particularly the conduct of Warder Henry Isaac Martin, and offers essential contextual material for understanding Wilde’s reflections on prison life.

state.p: Author, playwright, journalist, and poet associated with the Aesthetic and Decadent movements.

person.note:
Oscar Fingal O’Flahertie Wills Wilde (1854–1900) was an Irish playwright, novelist, essayist, and one of the central figures of the Aesthetic movement in late Victorian Britain. Celebrated in the 1890s for his sharp wit, public persona, and comedies of manners such as The Importance of Being Earnest, he fell spectacularly after his conviction for “gross indecency” in 1895. Sentenced to two years’ hard labour, Wilde was imprisoned in several institutions, including Reading Gaol, where he endured harsh conditions that profoundly marked his later writings.
After his release in 1897, he adopted the alias Sebastian Melmoth during his exile in France, where he lived in poverty but remained intellectually active. His prison experience produced De Profundis, a long epistolary meditation, and later inspired The Ballad of Reading Gaol (1898). Wilde’s posthumous reputation has grown considerably, and he is now regarded as one of the most distinctive voices of nineteenth-century literature, noted for his stylistic brilliance, social satire, and exploration of individuality, morality, and desire.

state.p: Prison governor in the British penal system, serving as Governor of Reading Gaol from 1896.
Known for his humane treatment of Oscar Wilde during Wilde’s imprisonment in Reading Gaol.

person.note: Major James O. Nelson served as Governor of Reading Gaol from 1896. He is remembered for his exceptional humanity toward Oscar Wilde during the latter’s incarceration (1895–1897). Nelson discreetly granted Wilde small but meaningful allowances: access to books; permission to resume reading and writing; and, most importantly, the opportunity to revise earlier portions of his manuscript. This gesture made possible the composition of De Profundis, Wilde’s long epistolary meditation written in Reading Gaol. After Wilde’s release, Nelson received presentation copies of The Ballad of Reading Gaol (1898) and The Importance of Being Earnest (1899), attesting to Wilde’s personal gratitude. Nelson’s legacy survives primarily through Wilde’s testimony, and he is recognised by modern Wildean scholarship as a rare figure of empathy within the Victorian penal system.

state.p: Journalist, art critic, gallery director, and literary executor of Oscar Wilde.
Close friend, long-term confidant, and later literary executor of Oscar Wilde.

person.note: Robert Baldwin “Robbie” Ross (1869–1918) was a Canadian-born British journalist, critic, and one of the most significant figures in the preservation of Oscar Wilde’s literary legacy. A loyal friend from the 1880s until Wilde’s death, Ross defended him publicly during moments of intense scandal, provided emotional and financial support after Wilde’s release from prison, and encouraged him to continue writing during his exile. After Wilde’s death in 1900, Ross assumed the role of literary executor and played a decisive role in editing, republishing, and safeguarding Wilde’s manuscripts and correspondence. His efforts not only contributed to Wilde’s posthumous reputation but also ensured that many of Wilde’s works survived intact. Ross was a central figure in London’s artistic and literary circles, notably through his involvement with The Carfax Gallery, which he co-founded. Remembered for his integrity, devotion, and influence on the dissemination of Wilde’s œuvre, Ross remains an essential figure in Wildean scholarship.

place.note:
Berneval-sur-Mer is a former coastal commune in the Seine-Maritime département (Normandy, France), today part of the commune of Petit-Caux. It was a quiet seaside village frequented by artists and writers in the nineteenth century.
After his release from Reading Gaol in May 1897, Oscar Wilde stayed in Berneval-sur-Mer under the pseudonym Sebastian Melmoth. He lodged at the “Hôtel de la Plage,” where he attempted to resume writing and rebuild his life in relative anonymity.
Wilde remained in Berneval from late May until September 1897, when he left France temporarily and travelled to Naples, where he lived for several weeks with Lord Alfred Douglas before returning again to France.
The letter edited in this TEI file was written from Berneval during this period of fragile recovery.

Reading Gaol (HM Prison Reading) is a Victorian prison located in Reading, Berkshire, United Kingdom (Forbury Road). The prison was built in 1844 on the model of the “separate system”, intended to enforce isolation and penitential reflection. It is most famously associated with Oscar Wilde, who was incarcerated there from 1895 to 1897 under the Criminal Law Amendment Act. Wilde described the harsh conditions of the establishment in several writings, and his experience there gave rise to The Ballad of Reading Gaol (1898), one of his major late works.

note.p:
My name is here,
Mons. Monsieur
Sebastian Melmoth
Hotel de la Plage
Berneval-sur-Mer.
Près de Dieppe

div.p:
I had of course
intended to write to you as
soon as I had safely reached
French soil, to express, however
inadequately, my real feelings
of what you must let me
term, not merely sincere, but
affectionate gratitude to you
for your kindness and gentleness
to me in prison, and for the real
care that you took of me
at the end, when I was mentally
upset and in a state of very
terrible nervous excitement. You
must not mind my using the
word ‘gratitude.’ I used to
think gratitude a burden to
carry. Now I know that it is
something that makes the heart
lighter. The ungrateful man
is one who walks slowly with
feet and heart of lead. But
when one knows the strange
joy of gratitude to God and
man the earth becomes lovelier
to one, and it is a pleasure
to count up, not one’s wealth
but one’s debts, not the little
that one possesses, but the
much that one owes.

I abstained from writing,
however, because I was haunted by
the memory of the little
children, & the wretched
half witted lad who was flogged
by the Doctor’s orders. I could
not have kept them out of
my letter, and to have mentioned
them to you might have put you
in a difficult position. In your
reply you might have expressed
sympathy with my views — I
think you would have — and then
on the appearance of my public
letter you might have felt as
I had, in some almost
ungenerous or thoughtless
way, procured your private
opinion on official things, for
use as corroboration.

I longed to speak to you
about these things on the
evening of my departure, but I
felt that in my position as a
prisoner it would have been
wrong of me to do so, and that
it would, or might have put
you in a difficult position
afterwards, as well as at the
time. I only hear of my
letter being published by a
telegram from Mr. Ross, but
I hope they have printed it in
full, as I tried to express
in it my appreciation and
admiration of your own humane
spirit and affectionate interest
in all the prisoners under
your charge. I did not wish
people to think that any
exception had been specially
made for me. Such exceptional
treatment as I received was by
order of the Commissioners. You
gave me the same kindness as
you gave to everyone. Of course
I made more demands, but
then I think I had really more
needs than others — and I lacked
often their cheerful acquiescence —

Of course I side with
the prisoners — I was one, and
I belong to their class now —
I am not a scrap ashamed of
having been in prison. I am
horribly ashamed of the materialism
of the life that brought me
there. It was quite unworthy of an
artist.

Of Martin, and the subjects
of my letter I of course say
nothing at all, except that
the man who could change the
system — if any one man can
do so — is yourself. At present
I write to ask you to allow
me to sign myself, once at any
rate in life,
